div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE SITUATION IN INDIA.
div.p: "Mr. Morley described the Indian situation quite accurately," says the “Spectator,” ''when he said that the Government of the Punjab, by prohibiting seditious meetings, bad allayed excitement in that great province, but that there was still anxiety there,' and, he might have added, throughout India. The seriousness of the situation, indeed, becomes clearer and clearer. It is impossible to read the telegrams which stream in almost day by day, with their accounts of incidents in Eastern Bengal and the Panjab and their translations from native papers everywhere, without perceiving that the class of educated natives which we have created, baffled in their ambitions, and with a new consciousness of their capacity, have decided that the only way to the realisation of their hopes lies through the overthrow of the British Government and the substituting for it of a Government, or many Governments, entirely native ; and to secure this end they are endeavouring, first of all, to excite the masses of the people by pouring our torrents of calumny, and secondly, to incite the native troops, and more especially the Sikhs, who are dreaded throughout India, to overt mutiny."

"To quit India and that, and nothing else, is the demand made on us-would be to abandon three hundred millions of people for whom we are morally trustees to all the evils of anarchy, without securing to them any of the advantages of independence. They do not perceive it, but it is a certainty that the withdrawal of Great Britain would be followed almost instantly by a partition of India among the Great Powers, both of Europe and Asia, who would spring at once-France upon Barma and Eastern Bengal, Russia upon the Northern Provinces, Germany upon Bombay and its hinterland, and China through Nepal upon Bengal proper, which they would regard as grand prizes, securing to them revenue and the monopoly of the vast markets for which they are all hangering. It is simply impossible for us to destroy in this way our own prestige, and to upset the general order of the world without any reason which can appeal either to our interests, our consciences, or our conviction that there are races in the world which are still in the position of minors, who must until they are full-grown be guided by other brains than their own."

"The most mysterious question in the whole movement, which puzzles, and to a certain extent dismays, the most experienced AngloIndians, is why it should have occurred at the present moment. An electric vibration is evidently passing over the peninsula, but its cause is absolutely invisible. The Government has done nothing good or bad that should rouse the people to resistance. There have perhaps, been blunders in the collection of the Land tax in the Punjab; but the movement is not confined to the Punjab, and Bengal is under the Perpetual Settlement. Neither the masses | nor the soldiery care one straw whether the alumni of the Colleges are provided for by the State or are left to find incomes by their own exertions. Indeed, one most remarkable feature of the whole movement is the absence of any definite grievance the removal of which would at once conciliate opinion. That India shared in the mental shock produced throughout Asia by the victories of the Japanese is undoubtedly true, and is acknowledged by every experienced official; but the Japanese are bound to the British Government by the strongest of all ties-a necessity for assistance if they are attacked by sea in their home waters and by a combination of Powers. The discontent has, in fact, manifested itself like a subterranean force which suddenly shatters cities, yet leaves the citizens powerless to explain, or even to understand, the oommotion. In 1857 the insurgents in their letters to each other made much of the fact that the British garrison had been reduced to its lowest point; but the garrison in India in 1907 never was so strong. There will be an explanation by and by; but for the present we have only to acknowledge a grave danger, and face it as our countrymen faced it fifty years ago, without fear, without cruelty, and without hesitation as to the rectitude of our decision to continue ruling."

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Four new cases of bubonic plague have been taken into hospital at Alexandria. One of these is a Greek barman of Rue des Soeurs, another a Greek grocer of the French Bazaar, and the remaining two are natives, both from the Custom House kism.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and July 25th 717,940 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 387,681 tons were Welsh, 102,460 Newcastle, 119, 127 Yorkshire, 57,790 Scotch, and 51,882 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 660,809.

div.p: We are informed that the Société Etablissements Orósdi-Back, whose central office is in Paris, has just published the report of the general meeting, which was held on the 19th inst. div.head: Regatta at Alexandria.
div.p: To-morrow afternoon at 4.30 o'clock a rowing regatta will be held in Alexandria Harbor. The four rowing clubs of the city, the Canottieri, Deutscher Sportsverein, Club Nantique Francaise and the Alexandria Row. ing Club, will all be represented. There will be four races, a sculling race, outrigger race, and two yawl races, one with four and one with two oars.

div.head: A Tourist in Old Egypt.
div.p: At King's College last week in connection with the Egyptian Exhibition being held there, Mr. H. R. Hall, of the British Museum, gave an account of recent excavation work at Thebes. Describing how he and a friend (Mr. Ayrton) spent some time living in the tomb of Rameses IV.. he said he noticed on a wall the following inscription by a Greek tourist of antiquity : "I have come here, but I see nothing to admire at all-except the big stone." People of the old days were very much like those of the present day, and like them scribbled remarks on the walls.

div.head: Esbekleh Gardens Theatre.
div.p: A farewell performance by the Gardet Troupe was given before a crowded house in the Esbekieh Garden Theatre on Wednesday evening when "Un fil à la patte'' was energetically rendered to an enthusiastic audience. We are pleased to be able to report that the tronpe, which has suffered so much this season from the shortage of money amongst the theatre-going populace of Cairo, recouped itself to a gratifying extent by last night's production. The prices paid for boxes and stalls was exceptionally good and a considerable profit was realised from the sale of dainty buttonholes by the charming actresses. Bon voyage.

div.head: A Nationalist Journalist.
div.p: Much comment has been aroused in Cairo owing to the assault made on a European journalist, belonging to a Cairo Nationalist European morning newspaper. This person was assaulted on Thursday evening on leaving the Garden Theatre by a Spaniard belonging to the troupe. The Spaniard says the "Journal du Caire," resented the assiduous attentions, which the nationalist journalist lavished on an artiste. Our French contemporary entitles 'the affair "Un Incident Passionnel” and declares that the journalist was brutally attacked. The combatants used their sticks and fista, but were separated before they had hurt one another seriously.

div.head: Suspected Plague.
div.p: The Director General of Quarantine at Port Said has telegraphed the following particulars of a suspected case of plague discovered on board a British 8.S., "Othello" :-The "Othel. lo" on arriving at Port Said from Hull disembarked a cooks mate, who has been ill for the past three days, and shows symptoms of plague; he has been transferred to the local lazaret and the necessary steps have been taken to isolate the possibly infected vessel, which has entered the canal in quarantine. Dr. Zirola has been charged with the bacteriological examination of the suspected case. The ship and crew were then medically inspected, with the result that a carpenter, who also shows symptoms of the disease, has been brought ashore.

div.head: PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE.
div.p: Continuing our reference to the report of Dr. Gostchlich on the Sanitary Services of the Municipality, we turn to his remarks on the work done by the Bureau des Meurs". The control exercised by this bureau is of great public importance, but, as Dr. Gostchlich points out, any really efficient supervision is im| possible among Europeans, firstly we should say, on account of the laxity of the regulations necessitated by the Capitulations, and secondly owing to the continual movement from one place to another and from this town to others of Egypt and abroad. The statistics given by the director of the Sanitary Services show that the proportion of diseased persons under observation is alarmingly high, the percentages for 1906 being 45 among natives and 30 among Europeans, as compared with the respective average percentages of 36 and 21 for the triennial period of 1903 to 1905.
We append Dr. Gntschlich's report on this service:-

"Les résultats obtenus par la surveillance des filles publiques, me font le devoir de répéter ce que j'ai déjà exposé dans mon rapport préc. dent au sujet des défectuosités du système actuel de contrôle; je dois y revenir cette année-ci d'autant plus que la | fréquence des maladies vénériennes en 1906 était de nouveau plus élevée que pendant les années précédentes. Cela tient surtout à ce que les femmes publiques, surtout celles appartenant à des nationalités étrangères, constituent ici une population éminemment fluctuante, de façon qu'un contrôle permanent -- la base de toute amélioration durable -- devient très difficile sinon impossible. On peut s'en rendre compte erf constatant que le nombre des filles ayant été sous observation ininterrompue depuis 1901 (date de l'organisation du bureau des maurs) ne forme qne la moitié environ du total existant pour les indigènes et même seulement les 10 % à peine pour les européennes. Chez ces dernières le mouvement annuel des filles entrées nouvellement et rayées pendant l'année est tel, qu'en 2 ans tout ce personnel est complètement changé ! Dans des conditions pareilles, l'on ne peut demander l'impossible d'un simple contrôle sanitaire et tout ce que nous pouvons faire c'est de soumettre tous les cas de maladies vénériennes constat's parmi les filles, à un traitement d'hôpital énergique."

DRINKING WATER SUPPLY.-Dr. Gotschlich next deals with the drinking water supply of Alexandria. The Jewel filters which are in use continue to work to the entire satisfaction of the sanitary authorities. As regards the clarification of water coming from the filters, it is declared that this is almost always of perfect limpidity. In spite of the fact that the water straight from the Mabmoudieh canal is sometimes so disturbed that one can distinguish nothing through a bed of only one centimetre's depth, the filtered water almost invariably is transparent up to and beyond 200 cm. The water from each filter is examined daily from the point of view of transparency, and it was only on nine occasions that the figure was inferior to the above. Even on those days, however, when the limpidity of the water was below normal, the quality of the water has always been irreproachable from a bacteriologi. cal point of view. The monthly average of the number of bacteria in one cubic centimetre of filtered water never exceeded 27, while the number of bacteria in the equivalent quantity of unfiltered water was about 4,700, whilst the highest figure reached for filtered water was 67, which shows an excellent comparison with more than 19,000 in unfiltered water. The filters are cleaned twice a week in the presence of sanitary inspectors, and it is notable that fifteen minutes after having been cleaned they invariably recovered their normal efficacy. Dur. ing 1906 there were 18,483 subscribers to the filtered water in town and 27 in Ramleh, with a daily water supply of 32,100 cubic metres, as compared with 29,000 cubic metres in 1905 supplied to 15,427 subscribers.

BUSINESS IN EGYPTIANS.

Owing to our weekly financial letter from our special correspondent in London having 'been delayed in the post, and consequently not having been received until this morning, we are unable to publish it in extenso. We append, however, our correspondent's re marks on Egyptian shares, written under date of the 19th inst. :-

Egyptians have followed the course of general stocks and shares this week, and business has been on a small scale. There has been a slight easing off in prices, but this is due to lack of support consequent on the holidays, etc., rather than to any specific adverse influences. An exception to the rule has been Delta Light Railway Preference, which have kept very firm. The price for these is now.99 . Delta Land and Investment are 1#-x.d. and Khedivial Mail are down to 15/16-1. National Bank of Egypt, after remaining fairly steady at 197, have fallen to 18 3/4-19, and Agricultural Bank 7 11/16-13/16, after being 7 9/16-11/16. Daira Sanieh have been dealt in at 131, and the Deferred are quoted 68-72 without any business to report. Egyptian Markets are firm at 28/, but Salt and Soda are only 16/6, at which price they changed hands yesterday. There have been few dealings in Egyptian Estates, the market price being 4-1. Land Bank of Egypt ore quoted 63-7, and New Egyptian 6-1. Union Fonciere have been hardly mentioned and close 41-5. There is nothing doing in Egyptian mining shares. Nile Valley leave off at 1/6 and Egyptian Mines Exploration at 1/-
Our correspondent also writes :

Anxiety is being expressed in some quarters as to what may be the result in the early autumn of the unquestioned demand for gold which will be required for the moving of the cotton crop in Egypt. Whilst it is certain that extensive shipments will have to be made for this purpose, there is no need for anxiety, inasmuch as the demand has been foreseen for some time past, and the banking community will without doubt be well able to meet all the calls that may be made upon it. These exports to Egypt may, of course, have the effect of raising the value of money, and may even lead to an increase in the Bank rate, but it is absurd to suppose that because Egypt has another bumper cotton crop, which must in the ordinary course of business be paid for, the whole business of the world will be upset by the gold requirements consequent on such prosperity. Moreover, the Bank is steadily strengthening, its position, and the reserve is now well within reach of the total at this period last year, as we are likely to be spared the heavy demands from America which were such a serious drain on our resources last summer, there is good reason to anticipate that there will be a very substantial reserve at the Bank before the Autumn exports begin.

div.head: · ASSIOUT TRAINING COLLEGE.
div.p: The American Presbyterian Mission is spending £20,000 on its new buildings at Assiout. | The site is at the head of the Ibrahimieh Canal near the Barrage, and embraces 25 acres. The foundation stone was laid last February under the auspices of the Synod of the Nile of the Evangelical Church of Egypt, and the building is now about & metre above ground. The erection is being made under the superintendence of Mr. F. S. Hoyman, a well-known American engineer from Pittsburg. The buildings in course of erection will be the central college, containing 35 rooms for administration, lectures, recitations etc., the Sawyer Memorial Science Hall, for the natural sciences, a large dormitory for 75 students, a residence for the professional staff and a ball for the Young Men's Christian Association. The plans for the latter buildings are now being prepared in Pittsburg. The grounds are being levelled and filled by Mr. C. S. Day, the Upper Egypt contractor. The general style of architecture will be of a simple and classic model.

The students at Assiout numbered 625 last term in the three departments, which give the pupils a thorough education in science, mathematics, literature, history, philosophy, eto. An interesting fact is that the Mission has found it necessary to abandon the teaching of French as the pupils have ceased to demand any instruction in that language. It is taught, if requested, but out of the 625 pupils at Assiont not more than half a dozen are learning French.

Dr. Alexander, the President of the College, is now spending the summer holidays in Switzerland. During his absence the administration of the college is in the hands, of Professor R. S. McClenahan. div.head: NEED FOR REFORM.
div.p: A correspondent writes from the Lebanon: -

The new Governor General of the Lebanon is arriving, and a new chapter opens in the history of this so-called privileged province. People are speculating on the nature of the new regime according to the color of their political inclinations. The neutral and disinterested few devoutly wish that, with this new nomination, a golden epoch may be inaugurated and a new leaf turned. Youssef Pasha, in fact, belongs to & family whose political career is not blackened with any records of corruption and unprincipled deeds, and a part of his own personal career was calculated to inspire in him the higher principles of justice and humanity. He was secretary to the Ottoman Delegation at the first Hague Conference, "the parliament of the world.” But in simple justice to the new Mutessarif we must not expect of him more than it is reasonably possible for him to give. The fact of his being an Ottoman sobject and an Ottoman functionary I places limits to his field of action, as any attempt on his part at a liberal progressive policy or at radical reform, is likely to be construed by his sovereign into disloyalty and treason. The late Governor, by merely indulging at the outset of his role in such dreams, incurred the imperial displeasure, although it was realized later that these dreams were mere soap bubbles lacking the backbone of serious purpose and earnest endeavour. Still the mere pose of reform was sufficient to alienate the sympathy and favour of Yildiz. The position of the Governor of the Lebanon is indeed an invidious one by the mere fact of the ambiguity of its independence. The powers in conceding what 'may have appeared to them at the time & were detail of delicacy have apparently not dreamt of the far reaching and sinister consequences of such a concession. It is one of the many instances of half-measures that in the end. were ruefully deplored.

The Lebanon stands in need of several radical reforms which the Governor dare not tackle, at the penalty of imperial disgrace. The constitution that had been elaborated for it, and given the important name of the "organic law," is at best a hastily and indifferently gotten up draft which may have been good enough for the primitive and insignificant province that the Lebanon then was, but which has grown quite antiquated and inadequate for present needs and conditions, hugely modified by such civilizing factors as emigration and contact with the outer world, and widespread education of a fairly high standard: The constitution of the Lebanon has thus come to be a ridiculous instance of anachronism. The subject is an important one, and requires to be dealt with at length and in detail, by an able student of political economy and law, and brought through an important organ of public thought, to the notice of the Powers. In a limited article of this kind a mere rough outline of the needed reforms may be attempted. By certain technical defects and the absence of proper safeguards in the framing of the constitution a legion of abuses have crept into the administration and drastic remedies have now to be applied for their removal beyond the risk or possibility of return. These minor abuses may be dealt with and incorporated in the general programme of reform involving the overhauling of the antiquated constitution. The sweeping work of radical reform must start with the proper reservey of the Lebanon and its proper delimitation, and the levying of the land tax accordingly. But fiscal reform need not stop within the limits of the constitution, which is far from being above fresh additions and emendations. A new tax on built property should be introduced now that the Lebanon, as a favourite summer resort, counts thousands of fine houses and hotels, which, absurd as it may seem, contribute next to nothing to the Lebanese treasury. The poll-tax has also to be levied according to a new census; and from these two items alone it is estimated that the revenue will more than double, and with this increase the budget may be so readjusted as to allow of the proportionate increase of expenditure, which is so sorely needed to provide adequate salaries to the civil functionaries and the militia. It is ridiculous to think that a mudir or sub-governor receives only £4 to £6 per mensem, and a judge about that sum, while a soldier receives only 4 piastres a day or a little more than sixpence. How can one expect such badly paid public servants to be scrupulously honest, now especially that living in the Lebanon has come to almost as dear as in Egypt. Then reforms will have to be introduced into the elective system of the Medjliss i e. the Administrative Council, a consultative body which, barring the executive, has practically the whole management of the internal affairs of the Lebanon relating to revenue and expenditure, public works etc. The members of this Medjliss are elected in a certain prescribed rotation, endowing them with a long term of office of six years, - by the mayors or sheikhs of the villages, who in turn are elected by the people. On the face of it, therefore, the election of the members of the Medjiss would appear to be an expression of the will of the people, but this is an illusion and sophism. The mayors being practically under the thumb of the members of the Medjliss, vote in accordance with the latter's dictation, so that the Administrative Council is practically self-elective.

It is not enough that the Lebanese have 3 been deprived of the vital benefits of a seaport enjoying steamship communication ; it is not enough that they have been locked up in a barren chain of mountains and deprived of at least, a bit of plain, and consequently o 5 every appreciable agricultural resource, but 11 they have been endowed with an inelastic
and antiquated constitution with inherent defects. With the general current of progress and by means of various factors, it has been the privilege of the Lebanon to be gratuitously blessed with, the economic and moral conditions of the population have developed beyond any sanguine anticipation, especially if we compare this with other provinces in the East and the execution of the reforms roughly outlined above compels therefore the attention of the Powers. Meantime the Governor General can by intelligent vigilance and an incorruptible integrity help in making the best of a bad case. He can help in preventing the faolty machinery of administration from being further clogged by the dust of neglect, and obstructed by all manner of abuses. By maintaining a strictly honest and fair attitude he deals & deadly blow to functionalism which is the bane of the Lebanon, and by keeping a watchful eye on bribery he disarms that whole band of intriguers whose sole occupation is to traffic with offices, purchasing and then exploiting the Rame mercilessly at the expense of the people. Moreover by disarming intrigue and blocking the path of bribery he wins that peace of mind which is a priceless boon, and places himself beyond that unwarrantable consularinterference which is so unworthily exploited by the said band of intriguers, and which is calculated to affect so much the dignity and rational independence of the Governor General. I can only speak in general terms and innuendoes. The Mutessarif of the Lebanon has a generous salary, sufficient, indeed, to enable him to lay aside a good fund of independence after even one term of office. We wish the new Governor General more than one “mandat", and we moreover wish he will withdraw with not only & material fortune but the better fortune of a good record and a good name.
"POLLIES” TO VISIT EGYPT.

We have this morning received a letter from Mr. Manrice E. Bandmann informing us that he has just arrived in Egypt to make arrangements for a visit of "The Follies." This is a first class combination of London stars and we are sure will be well appreciated by Mr. Bandmann's many Egyptian patrons. “The Follies" will arrive early next month and stay in Egypt for two weeks, viz one week in Cairo and a few nights at Alexandria. Several members of this excellent little combination have had the honour of appearing before his Majesty the King.

During his stay in Cairo, Mr. Bandmann hopes to conclude arrangements for some of his other companies to visit Egypt this coming season. The Bandmann Opera Company is at present meeting with great success in the Philippine Islands, and the Bandmann Comedy Company is playing at one of his Calcutta Theatres.

Mr. Bandmann's companies met with such great success on their last two visits to Egypt and were so enthusiastically received, especially by Cairene theatre goers, that we are sure the visit of "The Follies" will be welcomed.

div.head: THE LAW AFFECTING FOREIGNERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Scott, of the Khedivial Law School Cairo, is the author of an interesting and timely work on the Capitulations in Egypt, which should be the standard work on this intricate matter. The comprehensive character of the work can be seen from the following subjects of which it treats : The trade between East and West. Privileges granted to foreign merchants by the Christian states of the East. The rise of Islam. The trade of Egypt from the 12th to the 16th Century. The rights and privileges granted by the early Egyptian Capitulations. The Ottoman Capitulations and the French claim of protection. Religious Protection. The principal characteristics of the Ottoman capitulations. The tanzimat, or Reform in Turkey. The Ottoman laws of protec. tion and nationality. The land laws of Turkey and Egypt. Egyptand Turkey: the firmans and British Occupation. The privileges of the Capitulations. The privileges of Jurisdiction since the reform of 1876. The privileges of Jurisdiction and Legislation before the institution of the Mixed Courts in Egypt. Courts of personal Statute and Religious Communities. The privilege of Legislation since the reform of 1876. The future reform of the Capitulations.

"The Law Affecting Foreigners in Egypt as a result of the Capitulations, with an account of their origin and development by James Harry Scott. B.A., LLM, Advocate, Lecturer at the Khedivial School of Law, Cairo. Published by William Green and Sons, Law Publishers, Edinburgh 1907.

div.head: FRANCE AND EGYPT.
div.p: The Paris correspondent of the Daily Telegraph," writing on yesterday week, says

"The article which appeared iŋ the "Temps last evening, entitled "The Lambert affair Sir Edward Grey,” has attracted a great deal of notice. The point which the writer of this foreign bulletin wished to make particularly clear was that in her agreement with Great Britain, concluded in 1904, France had simply pledged herself to abandon all anti-English political action in Egypt. France had, he argued, a great stake in a country in which three milliards of her capital were invested, and with which she had had a long connection, and she was not disposed to surrender & single one of her rights The writer considered that wherever a Frenchman had held an official post, he ought to be succeeded by a compatriot 'and he laid particolar stress on the maintenance of the French schools, contending that they were & moral force."

div.head: AMERICAN EXPEDITION.
div.p: The New York Metropolitan museum's bulletin contains a report of the progress made in the excavations of the museum expedition at the Pyramids of Lisht. This is what is said of the discoveries in connection with the pyramid temple of Amenemhat I: -

The excavation of the temple site has yielded a very considerable amount of material from the original temple of Amenemhat, from which the main features of the structure can be determined. This includes many fragments and a number of complete blocks of painted relief from inscriptions and scenes on the palace wall. All the relief is most delicately and beautifully modelled, and in many cases has its colour still freshly preserved. Blocks bearing in baptions give the names of Amenemhat, a one case, those of Amenemhat and his son Usertessen I. jointly, from which it is certain the temple was constructed in par during the last ten years of Amenemhat I's reign, when, as we know, Usertesen acted as co-regent with him, or that it was finished after Amenemhat's death by Usertasen, who then placed his own name on the temple walls with that of his father.

While this excavation of the pyramid temple has been in progress work has boon carried on simultaneously for the last three months on the cemetery west of the pyramid. As was to be supposed from the proximity of the cemetery to the Royal tent of Amenembat its tombs are proving to be of important twelfth dynasty types, both in their construction and in the character of their do tente, "and their exos vation has been an important factor in the satisfactory results of the year.
The expedition will continue this great work next season,
